abstract.t: This document presents an extension that allows activities on social objects to be expressed within the Atom Syndication Format.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Atom Syndication Format, as defined in , is widely used to transmit various types of web content such as weblog posts, news headlines, as well as user activities within social sites. In the case of user activities, Atom lacks the ability to express much of the activity-specific metadata in a machine-parseable format. Activity Streams is an XML format designed to allow this additional activity metadata to be expressed within existing Atom entries and feeds.

It is a goal of this specification to provide sufficient metadata about an activity such that a consumer of the data can present it to a user in a rich human-friendly format. This may include constructing readable sentences about the activity that occurred, visual representations of the activity, or combining similar activities for display.

section.title: Notational Conventions
section.t: This document refers to elements in a number of XML namespaces as defined in . For brevity, these elements shall be referred to using prefixes rather than their full namespace URIs. The aliases used within this document are listed in the following table. The choices of namespace prefix are arbitrary and are not semantically significant.

This specification uses a shorthand form of terms from the XML Infoset . The phrase "Information Item" is omitted when naming element and attribute information items. Therefore, when this specification uses the term "element," it is referring to an element information item in infoset terms. Likewise, when this specification uses the term "attribute," it is referring to an attribute information item.

This specification allows the use of IRIs . Every URI is also an IRI, so a URI may be used wherever an IRI is named. When an IRI that is not also a URI is given for dereferencing, it MUST be mapped to a URI using the steps in Section 3.1 of . When an IRI is serving as an identifier, it MUST NOT be so mapped.
The text of this specification provides the sole definition of conformance. Examples in this specification are non-normative.
This specification uses "the Atom specification" to refer to .

section.title: Activity Concepts
section.t: In its simplest form, an activity consists of an actor, a verb, and an object. It tells the story of a person performing an action on or with an object -- "Geraldine posted a photo" or "John shared a video". In most cases these elements will be explicitly declared, but they may also be implied.

section.title: The Activity Construct
section.t: An activity consists of the following logical components:

section.title: ID
section.t: This absolute URI value conveys a permanent, universally unique identifier for the activity. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one ID value.

section.title: Icon
section.t: This URI value identifies an image resource which provides a visual representation of the activity, intended for human consumption. The image SHOULD be square and SHOULD be suitable for presentation at a small size. An Activity construct MAY have zero or one icon.

section.title: Time
section.t: A Date Construct, as defined in section 3.3 of , that identifies the time at which the activity occurred. It is important to note that this is not necessarily the same as the time at which the activity was published. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one Time value.

section.title: Actor
section.t: An Object Construct that identifies the entity that performed the activity. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one actor.

section.title: Verb
section.t: An absolute URI value that identifies the action of the activity. An Activity construct MUST have one or more verbs.

If an activity contains more than one verb, all verbs MUST be generalizations or specializations of one another. For example, the general verb "to experience" might be specialized by a verb "to listen to". If a more specific verb is used, publishers SHOULD also include all of its more general verbs so that a consumer may use the most specific verb it understands.

An activity consumer SHOULD use the most specific verb it understands within each entry. If none of the activity's verbs are understood by the consumer, it MAY use other information to infer the verb, or the consumer MAY use the content of the activity title, summary and/or content to obtain a human-readable description of the activity.

section.title: Object
section.t: This Object Construct identifies the primary object of the activity. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one object.

section.title: Target
section.t: The target of an activity is an Object Construct that represents the object to which the activity was performed. The exact meaning of an activity's target is dependent on the verb of the activity, but will often be the object of the English preposition "to". For example, in the activity "John saved a movie to his wishlist", the target of the activity is 'wishlist'. The activity target MUST NOT be used to identify an indirect object that is not a target of the activity. An Activity construct MAY have a zero or one target.

section.title: Generator
section.t: The generator of an activity identifies that application which created it, which may be separate from the service to which the activity is published. For example, a third-party application on a mobile phone may be used to post a photo to a photo sharing service. The activity generator is identified by a name and optional URI. An Activity construct MAY have zero or one generator.

section.title: Permalink URL
section.t: The URL of a HTML page that represents this activity. This property SHOULD NOT be null

section.title: Title
section.t: An HTML representation of the natural language title for this activity. Consumers MAY use the value of this field, if set, as a fallback for when none of the provided verbs are recognized. This property MAY be null if the publisher does not wish to provide a HTML representation.

section.title: Body
section.t: An HTML representation of a natural language describing this activity including visual elements such as thumbnails. Consumers MAY use the value of this field, if set, as a fallback for when none of the provided verbs are recognized. This property MAY be null if the publisher does not wish to provide a HTML representation.

section.title: Privacy
section.t: [TODO Review] An array of absolute IRIs which identify the privacy of the activity. This property MAY be null which denotes the privacy is obtained from the parent feed. Example: http://activitystrea.ms/privacy/1.0/public

section.title: The Object Construct
section.t: An object construct is a thing, real or imaginary, which participates in an activity. It may be the entity performing the activity, or the entity on which the activity was performed. An object consists of the following logical components:

section.title: ID
section.t: The id of an object construct is an absolute URI that uniquely identifies the object. An Object construct MUST have exactly one ID value.

section.title: Name
section.t: This string value provides a human readable display name for the object, if the object has a name. An Object construct MAY have a name, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: Summary
section.t: This string value provides a human readable description or summary of the Object. An Object construct MAY have a summary, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: Representative Image
section.t: This URI value identifies an image resource which provides a visual representation of the object, intended for human consumption. An Object construct MAY have a image, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: Permalink URL
section.t: This URI value identifies a resource which provides an HTML representation of the object. An Object construct MAY have a Permalink URL, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: Object Type
section.t: This absolute URI identifies the type of object. An Object construct MAY have one or more types.

If an object contains more than one object type, all types MUST be generalizations or specializations of one another. For example, the general type "article" might be specialized by the type "weblog entry". If a more specific type is used, publishers SHOULD also include all of its more general types so that a consumer may use the most specific type it understands.

Activity consumers SHOULD use the most specific object type that they understand within each entry. The consumer MAY use other information to infer the object type if it does not recognize any of the object types given. If it cannot infer the object type, a consumer MUST act as though no object type is present.

If no object type is present, the object has no specific type. Consumers SHOULD refer to such objects only by their titles. For example, when forming an activity sentence a consumer might say "Johan posted 'My Cat'" rather than "Johan posted a photo: 'My Cat'".

section.title: Atom Representation
section.t: Activities can be represented in an Atom document using a combination of conventions and custom extension elements. Activities are represented using atom:entry elements but may exist in one of two forms, an Activity Entry or an Object Entry.

section.title: Activity represented as atom:entry
section.t: Any valid Atom entry as defined by section 4.1.2 of is a representation of one or more activities as defined in .

If the atom:entry contains at least one activity:verb element and at least one activity:object element then it is a full activity entry and MUST be processed as described in . Otherwise the entry is an implied activity shorthand entry and MUST be processed as described in .

Although there is not a one-to-one mapping between an Atom entry and an activity, consumers SHOULD retain the value of the atom:id element from which each activity was produced such that these activities can be identified should an entry be referred to by another Atom feature which is not aware of the extensions defined in this specification. This id is not unique across all activities and has no semantic significance for Activity Streams processing.

section.title: Full Activity Entry
section.t: A full activity entry represents a selection of one or more activities which refer to different objects but all share the same values for the other activity properties.

The atom:author element which applies to the entry, as defined by section 4.2.1 of , represents the actor of the represented activities. This element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .

If the entry element has as a direct child an activity:target element then this element represents the target of the represented activities. This element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .
The atom:published child element of the entry, as defined in section 4.2.9 of , represents the time of the represented activities.
Each activity:verb child element of the entry represents a verb for the represented activities.

If the entry has as a direct child an atom:generator element then it MUST be processed as defined in section 4.2.4 of and its name and URI used for the generator property of the represented activities.

Each activity:object child element of the entry represents the object of an activity whose other properties are represented as described above. Each element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .
The set of activities represented by a full activity entry is the set of activities created by combining the object represented by each activity:object element with the other common properties.

section.title: Implied Activity Shorthand
section.t: An implied activity shorthand entry represents exactly one activity in terms of its object.
The atom:published child element of the entry, as defined in section 4.2.9 of , represents the time of the represented activity.

If the entry has as direct children one or more activity:verb elements, each of these elements represents a verb for the represented activity. If the entry has no activity:verb child elements, the represented activity is implied to have only the "post" verb as defined in [TODO: write this section and xref].
If the entry has as a direct child an atom:generator element then it MUST be processed as defined in section 4.2.4 of and its name and URI used for the generator property of the represented activity.

If the set of verbs for the represented activity includes the "post" verb, the atom:author element which applies to the entry, as defined by section 4.2.1 of , represents the actor of the represented activity. If the set of verbs does not include the "post" verb then the containing atom:feed element MUST have an atom:author element as its direct child and this element represents the actor of the represented activity. This appropriate atom:author element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .

The atom:entry element itself MUST also be processed into an object construct as defined in and used as the object of the represented activity. If the set of verbs for the represented activity does not include the "post" verb then the atom:published child element MUST be ignored when doing this processing, because the date therein represents the date of the activity and not the publication date of the object.
The represented activity of an implied activity shorthand entry does not have a target.

section.title: Object Representations
section.t: Object constructs are used to identify a number of different components in an activity, including the Actor and Object of an activity, among others. Depending on what an object is used to identify, it is rendered in Atom using a different root element, as defined in . The components of the object are represented using child elements as defined in .

section.title: Object element
section.t: Object constructs can be represented using the following elements:

list.t: When used to identify the object of an Implied Activity, an object is represented using the atom:entry element, as defined in .
When used to identify the Actor of an Activity, an Object is represented using the atom:author element, as defined in .
When used to identify the Object of an Activity, an Object is represented using the activity:object element.
When used to identify the Target of an Activity, an Object is represented using the activity:target element.
Other specifications or object types may define additional elements that can be used to represent objects.

section.t: The element used to represent the Object MAY have additional attributes and child elements that represent properties defined by the Object Types of the Object or by other extensions.

section.title: Object components
section.t: Unless specified otherwise, the components of an object are represented using child elements as follows, regardless of the element used to identify the object:

list.t: The ID of the object is represented using the atom:id element, as defined in section 4.2.6 of .
The name of the object is represented using the atom:title element, as defined in section 3.2.1 of .
The summary of the object is represented using the atom:summary element, as defined in section 4.2.13 of ).

The representative image of the object is represented by the href attribute of an atom:link element, whose rel attribute value is "preview" and a whose type attribute value is an appropriate image media type.
The permalink URL of the object is represented by the href attribute of an atom:link element, whose rel attribute value is "alternate" and whose type attribute value is "text/html".
Each object type URL of the object is represented as the content of an activty:object-type element.

section.title: Object represented as atom:author
section.t: When used to identify the Actor of an Activity, an Object is represented using the atom:author element (see section 4.2.1 of ). The components of the Object are represented using child elements as defined in , with the following exceptions:

list.t: The name of the Object is represented using the atom:name element, as defined in section 3.2.1 of .

The URL of the Object is represented by the href attribute of an atom:link element, whose rel attribute value is "alternate" and a whose type attribute value is "text/html". If no such atom:link element is present, consumers SHOULD accept the content of the atom:uri element as representing the Object Permalink URL.

section.title: RSS 2.0 Representation
section.t: Activities can be represented in an RSS 2.0.11 document, as defined by , using a combination of conventions and custom extension elements. An activity is represented using an RSS "item" element. The RSS serialization only supports a subset of the activity data model allowing descriptions of simple activities that have only a verb and an object. This serialization is optimized for posting activities describing the creation of new objects. Publishers with a need for representing other fields that are not catered for by this serialization are recommended to use the Atom serialization instead for best results. This RSS serialization is defined only as a means for those already publishing streams of objects as RSS to produce minimally useful list of activities for activity-aware consumers.

A specific RSS document has a single activity actor that applies to all activities it represents. This actor has no known id, name, url or object type but it is assumed that all activities in the feed share the same actor and therefore consumers MAY use information obtained from another source, such as the user account which is assumed to be the subject of the feed, to populate these properties.

section.title: Activity Represented as RSS "item"
section.t: In this section, "the item" refers to the RSS "item" element which is representing the activity.
An RSS "item" element represents exactly one activity in terms of its object.
The first pubDate child element of the item, as defined in , represents the time of the represented activity.

If the item has as direct children one or more activity:verb elements, each of these elements represents a verb for the represented activity. If the entry has no activity:verb child elements, the represented activity is implied to have only the "post" verb as defined in [TODO: write this section and xref].
The author of the activity is the feed-wide actor as described in .
The first title child element of the item, as defined in , represents the title of the activity's object.
If and only if the set of verbs for the activity includes the "post" verb, the first pubDate child element of the item, as defined in , also represents the publication time of the activity's object.

The first link child element of the item, as defined in , represents the URL of the activity's object. If no such element is present, the first guid child element which is marked as a permalink, as defined in , represents the URL of the activity's object.

The first guid child element of the item, as defined in , represents the id of the activity's object if and only if its value conforms to the syntax for an IRI as defined in . If it does not conform to this syntax, the activity's object has no id.
The activity represented by the item has no target.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: As this specification defines an extension to the Atom Syndication Format, it is subject to the same security considerations defined in .

Publishers or Consumers implementing Activity Streams as a stream of public data may also want to consider the potential for unsolicited commercial or malicious content and should take preventative measures to recognize such content and either identify it or not include it in their stream implementations.
Publishers should take reasonable measures to make sure potentially malicious user input such as cross-site scripting attacks are not included in the Activity Streams data they publish.
Consumers that re-emit ingested content to end-users MUST take reasonable measures if emitting ingested content to make sure potentially malicious ingested input is not re-emitted.

Consumers that re-emit ingested content for crawling by search engines should take reasonable measures to limit any use of their site as a Search Engine Optimization loophole. This may include converting un-trusted hyperlinks to text or including a rel="nofollow" attribute.

section.t: None.

section.t: This appendix is non-normative. Where these examples include fragments of XML documents, assume the namespace declarations xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:activity="http://activitystrea.ms/spec/1.0/" are in scope.
